Just to add to what J. B. is saying, I strongly recommend you keep to
the following rule: Each test should correspond to testing one thing in
one configuration state.

If you have 10 tests, and 4 different configurations you want to run
them in, that's (4 x 10 =) 40 tests in total. 

In JUnit, you don't have to write 40 test methods. You can get away
with 10, and run them in different suites. You can name the suites
whatever you like, but I recommend you name them so you can tell which
tests correspond to which configuration. 

(btw. Now it looks like you've got 40 tests instead of 10, your fellow
programmers will be very impressed by your productivity next time they
run the test suite! ;)

It's not cheating. You've got 40 tests, each testing something unique.
The important thing is to avoid situations where you have to explain
"these tests pass if you run them this way, but four of them fail you
run them that way". That's brings in complexity you just don't want in
your test suite.

On Sat, 2003-09-27 at 18:57, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> Rakesh wrote:
> 
> > Hi J.B., Jeff,
> > 
> > Thanks for the prompt reply.
> > 
> > I am extending MyTestCase from TestCase, as I am wishing to write a test
> > method in MyTestCase class as well.
> > Also, I am planning to club all small test suites in one test suite.
> > So there it makes sense.
> > 
> > Well, I did look at JUnit-Addons and GSBase, but as of now these doesn't
> > fit in my requirement.
> > I think I better stick with the idea suggested by Jeff.
> > I can write a function in Overridden TestCase class, which will set the
> > boolean variable.
> > And inside the test method I can check for this boolean variable.
> 
> Two problems with this technique:
> 
>   * Massive duplication within your test methods (the "should I run 
> this?" check)
>   * JUnit will report the test as executed, even if you immediately 
> return from it
> 
> I find the first problem to be serious. I find the second problem to be 
> worth fixing, but others do not.
> 
> I think it's a good first step, but it will annoy you pretty quickly. 
> Try it and see.
> 
> Good luck.
